Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, the invitation from my daughter-in-law still open on my phone. My grandson was finally going to share his college acceptance news with the whole family tonight, and everyone was expected to be there. I could already picture his proud, nervous smile, the way he’d look for my reaction first. But tonight was also Thursday, and I always attend the evening minyan at synagogue. It’s not a holiday, and the minyan will likely have enough people without me, but I know how much my presence matters to the regulars, and to myself. I’ve always believed in showing up, in being counted, in honoring my faith and community. Yet, my family expects me to be present for these milestones, to be the grandparent who never misses a moment. My heart aches as I imagine disappointing either side—missing my grandson’s big moment or letting down my synagogue friends. I stare at the clock, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which expectation I can bear to set aside.
